DataElement.preferredName: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma WHO Classification Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The WHO classification type for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by a diffuse proliferation of predominantly large neoplastic B lymphocytes.  It is the most frequently seen type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, representing 30%-40% of the cases.  Morphologic variants include centroblastic lymphoma, immunoblastic lymphoma, T-cell/histiocyte rich lymphoma, anaplastic lymphoma, plasmablastic lymphoma, and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with expression of full-length ALK. (WHO, 2001)_A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: This non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is characterized by a diffuse proliferation of predominantly large neoplastic B lymphocytes.  It is the most frequently seen type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, representing 30%-40% of the cases.  Morphologic variants include centroblastic lymphoma, immunoblastic lymphoma, T-cell/histiocyte rich lymphoma, anaplastic lymphoma, plasmablastic lymphoma, and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma with expression of full-length ALK. (WHO, 2001) -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A non-Hodgkin lymphoma characterized by a diffuse proliferation of predominantly large neoplastic B lymphocytes.  It is the most frequently seen type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma, representing 30%-40% of the cases.  Morphologic variants include centroblastic lymphoma, immunoblastic lymphoma, and anaplastic lymphoma.  Subtypes/entities include T-cell/histiocyte rich large B-cell lymphoma, primary diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the central nervous system, plasmablastic lymphoma, primary cutaneous diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, leg type, and ALK-positive large B-cell lymphoma.

Property.preferredDefinition: Classification; the grouping of things into classes or categories.

Concepts.definition: A method of generalization, the systematic arrangement of entities into classes or groups based on mutual similarity and certain differing characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 1/25/23 added alt name for ticket number CADSR0001948 for CCTG cjl.

PermissibleValues.value: B-cell lymphoma (unclassifiable) with features intermediate between diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and Burkitt lymphoma
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: High Grade B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified

ValueMeaning.preferredName: High Grade B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An aggressive lymphoma with morphologic features of both diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and Burkitt lymphoma, but without rearrangement of MYC gene, BCL2 gene and/or BCL6 gene.

Concepts.longName: High Grade B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified
Concepts.definition: High-grade B-cell lymphoma with blastoid features or features between diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and Burkitt lymphoma that lacks MYC, BCL2, and BCL6 gene rearrangements.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A term referring to a group of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas which are biologically heterogeneous and lack definitive and accepted criteria for further subclassification.  These lymphomas have a centroblastic, immunoblastic, or anaplastic morphology.

Concepts.longName: Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma, Not Otherwise Specified
Concepts.definition: A term referring to a group of diffuse large B-cell lymphomas which are biologically heterogeneous. These lymphomas have a centroblastic, immunoblastic, or anaplastic morphology.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
